A sum of finite numbers is still finite

type: ∀ {α : Type u_1} {s : Finset α} {f : α → ENNReal}, (∀ a ∈ s, f a ≠ ⊤) → (Finset.sum s fun a => f a) < ⊤
name: ENNReal.sum_lt_top
docString: A sum of finite numbers is still finite

Every natural number can be expressed as an even number (the sum of two identical numbers) or an odd number (2 times an integer plus 1).

type: ∀ (n : ℕ), Even n ∨ Odd n
name: Nat.even_or_odd
docString: Every natural number can be expressed as an even number (the sum of two identical numbers) or an odd number (2 times an integer plus 1).

This theorem states that the number 1 is not even. In the context of the definitions provided, an even number is defined as a number `a` that can be expressed as `a = r + r`, for some `r`. The theorem asserts that no such `r` exists for `a = 1`, i.e., 1 cannot be expressed as the sum of two identical numbers.

name: Mathlib.Data.Nat.Parity._auxLemma.10
docString: This theorem states that the number 1 is not even. In the context of the definitions provided, an even number is defined as a number `a` that can be expressed as `a = r + r`, for some `r`. The theorem asserts that no such `r` exists for `a = 1`, i.e., 1 cannot be expressed as the sum of two identical numbers.

The denominator is nonzero.

type: ∀ (self : ℚ), self.den ≠ 0
name: Rat.den_nz
docString: The denominator is nonzero.

The sum of two natural numbers is even if and only if both numbers are even or both are odd.

type: ∀ {m n : ℕ}, Even (m + n) ↔ (Even m ↔ Even n)
name: Nat.even_add
docString: The sum of two natural numbers is even if and only if both numbers are even or both are odd.

This theorem states that for all natural numbers `m` and `n`, the sum `m + n` is even if and only if `m` and `n` are both even or both odd. In other words, the parity of the sum of two natural numbers is the same as the parity of the individual numbers. Here, `Even` is a property of a number that is defined to be true if the number can be expressed as the sum of two equal numbers.

type: ∀ {m n : ℕ}, Even (m + n) ↔ (Even m ↔ Even n)
name: Nat.even_add
docString: This theorem states that for all natural numbers `m` and `n`, the sum `m + n` is even if and only if `m` and `n` are both even or both odd. In other words, the parity of the sum of two natural numbers is the same as the parity of the individual numbers. Here, `Even` is a property of a number that is defined to be true if the number can be expressed as the sum of two equal numbers.

name: Nat.dvd_right_iff_eq

type: ∀ {X : Type u_5} [inst : TopologicalSpace X], IsMeagre ∅

docString: The empty set is meagre.

The step function for the TM2 model.

type:
{K : Type u_1} →
  [inst : DecidableEq K] →
    {Γ : K → Type u_2} →
      {Λ : Type u_3} →
        {σ : Type u_4} → (Λ → Turing.TM2.Stmt Γ Λ σ) → Turing.TM2.Cfg Γ Λ σ → Option (Turing.TM2.Cfg Γ Λ σ)
name: Turing.TM2.step
docString: The step function for the TM2 model.

The translated TM0 machine (given the TM1 machine input).

type:
{Γ : Type u_1} →
  {Λ : Type u_2} →
    [inst : Inhabited Λ] →
      {σ : Type u_3} →
        [inst_1 : Inhabited σ] → (M : Λ → Turing.TM1.Stmt Γ Λ σ) → Turing.TM0.Machine Γ (Turing.TM1to0.Λ' M)
name: Turing.TM1to0.tr
docString: The translated TM0 machine (given the TM1 machine input).

All denumerable types are equivalent.

type: (α : Type u_3) → (β : Type u_4) → [inst : Denumerable α] → [inst : Denumerable β] → α ≃ β
name: Denumerable.equiv₂
docString: All denumerable types are equivalent.

The semantics of TM1 evaluation.

type:
{Γ : Type u_1} →
  [inst : Inhabited Γ] →
    {Λ : Type u_2} → {σ : Type u_3} → Turing.TM1.Stmt Γ Λ σ → σ → Turing.Tape Γ → Turing.TM1.Cfg Γ Λ σ
name: Turing.TM1.stepAux
docString: The semantics of TM1 evaluation.

A product of finite numbers is still finite

type:
∀ {ι : Type u_1} {R : Type u_8} [inst : CommMonoidWithZero R] [inst_1 : NoZeroDivisors R] [inst_2 : Nontrivial R]
  [inst_3 : DecidableEq R] [inst_4 : LT R] {s : Finset ι} {f : ι → WithTop R},
  (∀ i ∈ s, f i ≠ ⊤) → (Finset.prod s fun i => f i) < ⊤
name: WithTop.prod_lt_top
docString: A product of finite numbers is still finite

Two pre-sets are equivalent iff they have the same members.

type: ∀ {x y : PSet}, PSet.Equiv x y ↔ PSet.toSet x = PSet.toSet y
name: PSet.Equiv.eq
docString: Two pre-sets are equivalent iff they have the same members.

A sum of numbers is infinite iff one of them is infinite

type:
∀ {ι : Type u_1} {M : Type u_4} [inst : AddCommMonoid M] {s : Finset ι} {f : ι → WithTop M},
  (Finset.sum s fun i => f i) = ⊤ ↔ ∃ i ∈ s, f i = ⊤
name: WithTop.sum_eq_top_iff
docString: A sum of numbers is infinite iff one of them is infinite

Sums of measurable spaces are symmetric.

type:
{α : Type u_1} →
  {β : Type u_2} →
    {γ : Type u_3} →
      {δ : Type u_4} →
        [inst : MeasurableSpace α] →
          [inst_1 : MeasurableSpace β] →
            [inst_2 : MeasurableSpace γ] → [inst_3 : MeasurableSpace δ] → α ≃ᵐ β → γ ≃ᵐ δ → α ⊕ γ ≃ᵐ β ⊕ δ
name: MeasurableEquiv.sumCongr
docString: Sums of measurable spaces are symmetric.

The geometric pmf is measurable.

type: ∀ {p : ℝ}, Measurable (ProbabilityTheory.geometricPMFReal p)

No zero divisors.

docString: No zero divisors.

Two inseparable points in a T₀ space are equal.

type: ∀ {X : Type u} [inst : TopologicalSpace X] [self : T0Space X] ⦃x y : X⦄, Inseparable x y → x = y
name: T0Space.t0
docString: Two inseparable points in a T₀ space are equal.

The torsion subgroup is finite.

type: (K : Type u_1) → [inst : Field K] → [inst_1 : NumberField K] → Fintype ↥(NumberField.Units.torsion K)
docString: The torsion subgroup is finite.
